did.unittitle: Jesse Pyrant Andrews photographs and oral histories

physdesc.physfacet: 79 .wav format files (35.6 gigabytes); 79 .mp3 format use copy files (3.2 gigabytes)

did.abstract: Jesse Pyrant Andrews (b. 1949) is an American photographer based in rural southern Virginia. Collection comprises 257 black-and-white photographs and 39 oral interviews by Jesse Pyrant Andrews documenting rural and small-town life in the Piedmont plateau of central southern Virginia and northern North Carolina. Major themes center on the landscapes and people of the region; tobacco cultivation; the lives of farmers, war veterans and laid-off workers; local architecture and historic sites; traditional crafts and music; and new patterns of economics and society in rural Virginia. The materials also include a Vietnam War veterans manuscript memoir and numerous oral histories of veterans. Additional projects include documentary narrative about the southern Virginia Carter-Wooding families; views from an Amtrak train; and street scenes and portraits taken in New York City, California, and Massachusetts. Acquired as part of the Archive of Documentary Arts at Duke University.
did.physdesc: Original negative identifiers and titles assigned by the photographer have been retained. The original identifier on the back of each print typically comprises codes for the body of work, negative file, and negative number. There are a few unnumbered prints. In the case of untitled works, descriptions in brackets have been supplied by library staff. Each print also has been given a Rubenstein Library identifier. Most of the photographs were printed by Andrews in his darkroom from the early 2000s to 2020.

dao.xlink:title: Jesse Andrews Photographs

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in the following series: 13-Month Crop: One Year in the Life of a Piedmont Virginia Tobacco Farm; Bill Davis and Davis Family; Portraits; Virginia; Train Project, View from Amtrak Northeast Regional; Burlington Mills; and Life at Large and Other Work. There is also a series for original media.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Documentary photographer and oral historian Jesse Pyrant Andrews (b. 1949) has photographed the changing rural landscapes of Virginia and North Carolina and the lives of its inhabitants since the mid 1970s. His documentary projects include in-depth oral history interviews that provide an important context for his portraits of Virginia veterans, farmers, immigrants, and former textile mill workers. Andrews studied at the New England School of Photography in Boston, Massachusetts, working primarily with photographers Olive Pierce and George Dewolfe. He shoots 35mm black-and-white film which he prints in his traditional darkroom.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Collection is partially restricted.

Original audiovisual media are closed to use; digital copies are available and can only be accessed onsite in the Rubenstein Library Reading Room. To request access, please contact Research Services before coming to use these records.

userestrict.head: Copyright Notice
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. Images are restricted to educational, non-commercial purposes; any other use requires permission of donor. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Jesse Pyrant Andrews photographs and oral histories were received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as purchases from 2003 to 2020.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: Digital oral history use copy files were derived from optical discs and consist of audio files in .wav (preservation copies) and .mp3 format (use copies).

processinfo.p: Originally processed by Elizabeth Arnold, John Mayrose, 2007.
Updated and processed by Paula Jeannet and Matthew Warren, December 2012; Clare Callahan and Paula Jeannet, August 2013; and Paula Jeannet, 2015-2021.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: Collection comprises 257 black-and-white photographs and 39 oral interview recordings by Jesse Pyrant Andrews documenting rural and small-town life in the Piedmont plateau of central southern Virginia and northern North Carolina. Most of the images are portraits of farming families, immigrant workers, former textile workers, war veterans, musicians, and other local people, with scenes from homesteads, small towns, farms, and grave sites. Major themes include tobacco cultivation; the lives of war veterans and laid-off workers; regional architecture and historic sites; and traditional activities such as music-making, making handmade firearms, and working with leather. Together, the images and interviews speak to enormous changes in this rural Piedmont region as it transitions into the 21st century.

Three bodies of work whose images are found in the Portraits and Virginia series are referred to by Andrews as the Veterans, Vietnam, and Carter-Wooding Projects. The first two document the lives and struggles of U.S. veterans of World War II and the Vietnam and Gulf wars, and includes many audio interviews. The second project, also accompanied by several oral histories, documents two Halifax County, Virginia families, the Carters and Woodings, and their rural property which dates back to an 18th-century Huguenot land grant. The materials also include a Vietnam War manuscript memoir.

Additional photo projects in the collection document the lives of former textile workers (also accompanied by oral histories); a trip on an Amtrak train; and street life and people in New York City, California, and Massachusetts.
Most of the photographs are accompanied by captions written by the photographer, commenting on the individuals, their life experiences, and aspects of local culture and society.
Photographs from the series documenting tobacco farming, "13-Month Crop," were selected for a 2002 exhibit of Andrews' work hosted by the Rubenstein Library at Duke University.
A large selection of photographs in this collection has been digitized and is available online as part of the Duke Digital Collections.

did.unittitle: 13-Month Crop: One Year in the Life of a Piedmont Virginia Tobacco Farm

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series contains 38 11x14 inch black-and-white (gelatin silver) prints exhibited at Duke University's Perkins Library, August 7-December 14, 2002. Andrews spent one tobacco farming season, April 2000 to April 2001, using a traditional film camera to document the lives of the people who were involved in cultivating tobacco on the Moore family farm in Pittsylvania County, Virginia. Images portray the white farm family members as well as migrant Latino farmworkers. Tobacco farming is such labor-intensive work that it is often called a "13-month crop."

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Titles, captions, and original negative identifiers assigned by the photographer have been retained. Prints are arranged in rough chronological order according to the negative date.

did.unittitle: Bill Davis and Davis family

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series is made up of 18 11x14 inch black-and-white (gelatin silver) photographs, the majority of which feature portraits of Bill and Nat Davis, brothers from an established rural family from the Piedmont plateau region of Pittsylvania County in south-central Virginia. Images range from the landscapes and sites around this family farm to the portraits of the two brothers Bill and Nat. One includes a sister, Nancy Paige Davis. There are several images of Bill's burial and gravesite.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Titles, captions, and original negative identifiers assigned by the photographer have been retained. Prints are in original order as assigned by the photographer.

did.unittitle: William Arastus Davis (Bill), 1988

dao.xlink:title: William Arastus Davis (Bill), 1984

did.unittitle: Bill Davis braiding a belt from deer hide, 1988

dao.xlink:title: Bill Davis braiding a belt from deer hide, 1988

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Bill learned to braid leather when he was a child. His father did not want him to learn that craft so he would take the strands of leather under the covers of his bed at night and practice braiding simply by feel. He could do any sort of braid from the most simple to making what he called a "rosette," a round knot woven from 16 strands of leather, seemingly with no beginning or end.

did.unittitle: Bill Davis playing a chromatic harmonica, 1988

dao.xlink:title: Bill Davis playing a chromatic harmonica, 1988

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The chair he is sitting in was made by his grandfather, Simeon Benton Davis.

did.unittitle: Bill Davis with his younger sister, Nancy Paige Davis, 1990

dao.xlink:title: Bill Davis with his younger sister, Nancy Paige Davis, 1990

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Bill was much older than Nancy. When she turned 18, she wanted to attend the nursing school at the University of Virginia, but their father refused to pay for her to go. Bill eventually saved enough money to send her and she graduated in 1941. She never returned to the farm except to visit and lived in Richmond until her death in 2005. This image was made during her last visit to see Bill. She always referred to him as her angel and thus she was making a halo for him.

did.unittitle: William Arastus Davis (Bill Davis), 1900-1991, on the Davis Farm near Chatham, Virginia, 1976

dao.xlink:title: William Arastus Davis (Bill Davis), 1900-1991

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Bill was a friend of my grandmother. When I was a child, she would take me with her to visit the Davis farm. I knew the Davises very well. They are all dead now, their farm sold and is now a high-end housing development. The Davis family was a real link to the past. They never got accustomed to the Twentieth Century.

did.unittitle: Bill Davis fleshing out a deer hide, Chatham, Virginia, 1982

dao.xlink:title: Bill Davis fleshing out a deer hide, Chatham, Va., 1982.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Bill would tan fresh deer hides to use in his leather work. He made a device which would split a hide into evenly sized strips for braiding. He made belts, sashes, hat bands, watch fobs, key holders, and guitar straps. He also did harness repairs and remade worn out shoes. But the first step in this process was to pick all the flesh off the hide. If left, the bits of flesh would attract insects to eat the hide and leave uncured spots on the finished hide.

did.unittitle: Portraits

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series consists of 48 11x14 inch black-and-white portraits of individuals taken by photographer Jesse Pyrant Andrews in Virginia and North Carolina, with a few from Tennessee and California. Subjects include men and women, teenagers, and fathers and mothers with their sons, chiefly from rural areas and small towns. The series includes portraits of war veterans who served in World War II, Vietnam, and the Iraq War, and which form part of Andrews' Veterans Project (also incorporating his Vietnam Project). These portraits have accompanying biographical captions and oral history recordings. The portrait of Vietnam veteran Donald Wright is also accompanied by Wright's handwritten journal describing events in Vietnam and after the war.
As portraiture is one of the photographer's favored formats, additional portraits - sometimes of the same people in this Portraits series - are found in other project series.
Titles and original negative identifiers assigned by the photographer have been retained. Prints in this series are arranged in order as received.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The oral histories accompanying the prints are open to research use. As they require additional preparation time for access, please contact the Rubenstein Library before coming to use this materials.

did.unittitle: Joe Thompson at home, Mebane, North Carolina, 2003

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Born in 1919, Joe Thompson was the last of his generation to play American "old time" music, in a style which evolved among black musicians in the rural South as far back as the antebellum years. Joe's playing had a unique sound and rhythm, shaped by his association with older musicians in his childhood and by continuing to play with other black "old time" musicians throughout his life. His cousin Odell played banjo with him until his death. Joe Thompson was a veteran of WWII. Trained as a bulldozer operator, he told me that he "built roads and buried bodies from Normandy to Berlin." He worked in the former White Furniture factory in Mebane until his retirement. He died in 2012.

did.unittitle: Gary Lynch, Franklin County, Virginia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Gary Lynch grew up hard on a Franklin County tobacco farm. His father made white liquor and was in and out of jail. Gary was very much influenced by his grandomther, who taught him to love gardening and famring. He later earned a BS in horticulture and has been very successful with that career. Oral history accompanies this print.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The oral history is open to research use. As it requires advance preparation for use, please contact the Rubenstein Library before coming to use this material.

did.unittitle: George P. Hunt, Jr. (Toby), South Boston, Virginia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: George Hunt's father was editor of Life magazine from 1960-1968. During this time, Toby worked in the photo lab and equipment room of the magazine and often accompanied Life photographers on assignments as an assistant. He knew the great photographers of that era, Eugene Smith, Ralph Morse, Larry Burroughs, and others. Oral history accompanies this print.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The oral history is open to research use. As it requires advance preparation for use, please contact the Rubenstein Library before coming to use this material.

did.unittitle: Richard Patterson, Pittsylvania County, Virginia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Richard Patterson served as an Army Airborne medic from 1952 until 1978. He spent 1968 and 1969 in the Mekong Delta of Vietnam as a medic with the 25th Infantry during which time he participated in 24 search and destroy missions. He suffers from diabetes as a result of exposure to Agent Orange.
Oral history accompanies this print. Part of the Veteran's Project.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The oral history is open to research use. As it requires advance preparation for use, please contact the Rubenstein Library before coming to use this material.

did.unittitle: Lee Mall, Halifax County, Virginia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lee Mall served as an infantryman with C Co., 1st Battalion, 46th Division of the 198th Light Infantry Brigade in the Central Highlands of Vietnam from March of 1968 until March of 1969. He was present when LZ Professional was overrun by NVA [North Vietnamese Army] forces.
Oral history accompanies this print. Part of the Veterans Project.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The oral history is open to research use. As it requires advance preparation for use, please contact the Rubenstein Library before coming to use this material.

did.unittitle: John Payne, Lunenburg County, Virginia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: John Payne served as an infantryman with the 1st Air Cavalry, then with the 101st Airborne in the Central Highlands of Vietnam, later in the Mekong Delta south of Saigon. His platoon lost 19 of 25 men in a two day firefight in the A Shau Valley on the 15th April, 1971.
Two oral histories, recorded by Andrews in separate sessions, accompany this print. Part of the Veterans Project.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The oral history is open to research use. As it requires advance preparation for use, please contact the Rubenstein Library before coming to use this material.

did.unittitle: Fred Behrens, Powhatan, Virginia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Fred Behrens served with the 326th Medical Battalion of the 101st Airborne Division in the Central Highlands of Vietnam from May of 1970 until June of 1971, first as an assault helicopter pilot and later as a medivac (dustoff) pilot, based at Phu Bai. On 23 April 1971, while flying into an intense firefight in the A Shau valley, his helicopter was shot down. Wounded five times, he hid in the jungle for two days until he was rescued.
Oral history accompanies this print. Part of the Veterans Project.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The oral history is open to research use. As it requires advance preparation for use, please contact the Rubenstein Library before coming to use this material.

did.unittitle: Chris Cole, Halifax, Virginia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Chris Cole served with the 5th Battalion of the 11th Marine Corps Division during the initial invasion of Iraq in March of 2003.
Oral history accompanies this print. Part of the Veterans Project.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The oral history is open to research use. As it requires advance preparation for use, please contact the Rubenstein Library before coming to use this material.

did.unittitle: Couple at family reunion, Whittles, Virginia
Bill Jenkins, Rice, Virginia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Since 1964, Bill Jenkins has operated Jenkin's Blue and Gray Wayside, a general/convenience store established by his grandfather in the 1950s. Bill is an exceptionally friendly man who has met and befriended people from all over the world while operating the store. He is a fascinating story teller and loves talking about the people he has met as well as his dedication to and involvement in his community. Stores like Jenkin's and people of Bill's open and accepting nature are fast becoming a part of history.
Two-part oral history accompanies this print, conducted by Andrews on September 22, 2017 (RL00043-CD-0028 to -0030) and February 13, 2018 (RL00043-CD-0031 to -0033).

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The oral history is open to research use. As it requires advance preparation for use, please contact the Rubenstein Library before coming to use this material.

did.unittitle: Bob Cage at his farm, Shanti, Halifax County, Virginia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bob Cage grew up in Halifax, Virginia, serving in the Marine Corps during WW2. He later became a nationally ranked tennis player, and won the world's championship tobacco auctioneering contest in 1984. He was a prolific painter and sculptor, working primarily with found materials. His paintings and sculptures can be seen around Halifax and South Boston. He was a key figure in the fight against uranium mining in Virginia. He died in 2014 at age 91.

did.unittitle: Donald Wright, Tightsqueeze, Virginia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Served in the Marine Corps, 1968-1975, first as a squad sergeant with A Co., 1/7th of the 1st Marine Division west of Da Nang, then with the 1st Marine Recon Battalion. Oral history and handwritten account accompany this print. Part of the Vietnam Project.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The oral history is open to research use. As it requires advance preparation for use, please contact the Rubenstein Library before coming to use this material.

did.unittitle: Donald Wright, Vietnam War memoir (1968-1973)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sgt. Donald Wright's memoir begins in September 1968 with his arrival at Da Nang, and ends in 1973 when he re-enlisted. The narrative is sometimes non-linear, jumping from memory to memory. Wright recalls battles, operations, life and leisure at military bases and camps, civilians in the war, Viet Cong attacks, Viet Cong child soldiers, a mine sweep on Liberty Road, a court-martial murder case, being wounded in combat, bonding with other soldiers in the Army, religious reflections, thoughts of home, and homecomings.

According to his memoir, Sgt. Donald Wright first served as squad leader in the 3rd Guard, 3rd Platoon, Alpha Co. 1/7 1st Marine Division; later, he was promoted to Corporal and became an MP (Military Police). Battles described in detail include Memorial Weekend Battle, Meade River, Lynn River, and the Tet Offensive.

The memoir is handwritten, with edits and side commentaries. Two sets of loose pages describing other memories are laid in. Also included are a few patches and an undated memorial program for George Alfred Marks, Jr. (1945-1968), member of the 1st Battalion, 7th Marines Division, location of memorial is given as the Republic of Vietnam. Marks died there in November 1968 (Source: Find a Grave website, February 2021).

did.unittitle: Rev. Donald Wilson, Buffalo Junction, Virginia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Ordained as a Baptist minister in 1962, Donald Wilson served as Chaplain in the U.S. Army for 26 years. He spent a year with an infantry company at LZ West, near Da Nang, South Vietnam, 1968-69, accompanying them on patrols and into firefights, even though he never carried a weapon. After his service in Vietnam, he served as Chaplain at Army bases around the world, including becoming Chaplain at West Point. Oral history accompanies this print. Part of the Vietnam Project.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The oral history is open to research use. As it requires advance preparation for use, please contact the Rubenstein Library before coming to use this material.

did.unittitle: Dianne Gagliano, Charlottesville, Virginia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Colonel Gagliano joined the U.S. Air Force Nurse Corps in 1967. She served for 18 years as a flight nurse in both the Pacific and Atlantic Aeromedical, accruing over 2000 in-flight patient hours. This included six years in Vietnam, evacuating wounded servicemen to hospitals in other countries where they could receive the care they needed. These flights involved gruelling 24-hour days aboard a huge C-141 cargo plane which had been reconfigured with cots, IV poles, and other medical equipment to care for the wounded. Flights carried between 80 and 100 patients. They would fly from the Philippines to Saigon, then to Da Nang, picking up patients along the way; then to Guam, Hawaii, Japan, Alaska, and California, dropping off patients according to their needs, then return to the Philippines. They made two flights a week, typically. She later served as a flight nurse in Operation Desert Storm and in Afghanistan. In all those years, she lost only one patient. She also participated in the airlift of POWs from Hanoi in 1973, as well as in Operation Saigon Baby Lift in 1975, helping to evacuate several thousand orphaned children from South Vietnam, many of whom were children of American servicemen who had served there. Col. Gagliano was also an influential force in the creation and dedication in 1993 of the Women's Memorial in Arlington, Virginia. She retired after 26 years of service. Oral history accompanies this print. Part of the Vietnam Project.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The oral history is open to research use. As it requires advance preparation for use, please contact the Rubenstein Library before coming to use this material.

did.unittitle: Rose and Harold Hughes, Virgilina, Virginia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Harold Hughes served as an infantryman with the 1/26 Infantry in Vietnam from February 1967 until July 1968. He was severely wounded by mortar fire while on patrol in the Central Highlands. His wife, Rose, initiated an effort to establish a chapter of Vietnam Veterans of America in South Boston, Virginia, as a way of bringing Vietnam vets together. Strength in unity. Oral history accompanies this print. Part of the Vietnam Project.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The oral history is open to research use. As it requires advance preparation for use, please contact the Rubenstein Library before coming to use this material.

did.unittitle: Charles Throckmorton, Scottsburg, Virginia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Charles Throckmorton served with the 198th Infantry, part of the Americal Division, in the Central Highlands near Chu Lai, South Vietnam, from September 1968-September 1969.
Oral history accompanies this print. Part of the Vietnam Project.

did.unittitle: David Kipfinger

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Enlisted in U.S. Army in January, 1966. In December 1967 was sent to Vietnam as an infantryman with the 1st Air Cavalry. In December 1968 he trained as a a scout and was sent to An Khe, participating in patrols in the Bong Son Plain in the Central Highlands. Later served as a machine gunner in the A Shau Valley, where he was wounded and also suffered from heat stroke. He was sent to the rear to recover. When he was sent back to his unit they were pinned down for a month by NVA artillery fire near Quang Tri, with little resupply, but finally relieved by repeated airstrikes on the NVA positions. "Any person who has been in combat and comes back suffers in some way from PSTD. They have seen or heard or been involved with something that was very difficult to get rid of." Oral history accompanies this print. Part of the Veterans Project.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Oral history is open for research. As it requires advance preparation for use, please contact the Rubenstein Library before coming to use this material.

did.unittitle: Warren Richardson

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Drafted into U.S. Army in November, 1969. Trained with Aviation as a helicopter mechanic, maintaining CH47 (Chinook) helicopters (the larger ones with two rotors). He was sent to Vietnam in July, 1970, where he was assigned to the Americal Division at Chu Lai. He repaired Chinooks that were shot up, and did routine maintenance, and when not otherwise occupied, served as a door gunner or navigator on those same helicopters. Left service in July, 1971. Oral history accompanies this print. Part of the Veterans Project.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Oral history is open for research. As it requires advance preparation for use, please contact the Rubenstein Library before coming to use this material.

did.unittitle: Curtis Millner

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Joined U.S. Army in 1970, "because of a broken heart." Only 17 at the time, he altered his birth certificate to make him appear to be 18. After basic training, he was sent to Ft. Belvoir and trained as a truck and large equipment mechanic. He worked with the 17th Combat Engineers for 18 months at Ft. Hood, Texas. Was sent to Vietnam and was stationed at Cam Ranh Bay with the 577th Engineers. He was later made Sgt. of the Guard at Long Binh, in charge of five miles of perimeter around that base, the largest U.S. base in Vietnam, subject to daily rocket and mortar attacks and attempts by the NVA to overrun the base. After his time in Vietnam he spent nine more years in service, with tours in Germany and Korea. Was promoted to Warrant Officer and retired in 1983.
Oral history accompanies this print. Part of the Veterans Project.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Oral history is open for research. As it requires advance preparation for use, please contact the Rubenstein Library before coming to use this material.

did.unittitle: Armin Barnett, Halifax County, Virginia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Armin Barrett, born in Chicago and educated at the University of Virginia, returned to Chicago and served a four year apprenticeship in violin making at Kenneth Warren and Son, a long established instrument making shop. He opened his own shop in Seattle in 1977 and continues now to repair and make violins, violas and cellos. An accomplished musician in the Irish-American genre as well as American "old time" music, Armin primarily plays fiddle, but also banjo and guitar. He knows and has played with the most famous players in the world. A longtime friend, Armin is possessed of a wonderful sense of humor and a direct but compelling nature.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access

did.unittitle: Armin Barrett and Kinney Rorrer, Blairs, Virginia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Kinney Rorrer is a historian and musicologist. Posey Rorrer, his great uncle, was the fiddle player in Charlie Poole's band the New North Carolina Ramblers, who recorded hit records for Victor in the 1920s. Kinney plays banjo in the style of Charlie Poole, and the banjo he is holding (which he plays regularly) belonged to Charlie Poole.

Apprenti boulanger (Elise Lloyd)
Claude Dewey Boswell, Pittsylvania County, Virginia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Dewey Boswell was my maternal grandmother's brother, the youngest of five, born in 1899. During Prohibition he made and sold white liquor. He played clawhammer banjo in an "old time" band that he and his brothers formed before World War I. Later he farmed and worked as a housepainter.

did.unittitle: William Cabell Shotwell, Halifax County, Virginia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: William Shotwell grew up on a tobacco farm in the Virgilina Community of Halifax County, Virginia. He was drafted into service in 1966 and spent most of 1967 and 1968 with the 185th Light Maintenance Battalion, stationed at Long Binh, the largest American base in Vietnam, just north of Saigon. He worked as a maintenance mechanic at Long Binh and participated in numerous search and destroy missions after the Tet offensive of 1968.
An oral history and release form accompany this print. Part of the Vietnam Veterans Project.

did.unittitle: Frank Joseph Wilcosky, Jr. and his brother, Timothy Wilcosky, Chapel Hill, North Carolina

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Joe and Tim have been very close since childhood. Tim earned his undergraduate degree from Duke University in zoology in 1971. He then earned a degree from Ohio State University in Preventive Medicine, followed by his degree in Public Medicine (epidemiology) from UNC. Tim worked as an epidemiologist until his retirement.

did.unittitle: Dr. Ralph Stanley on his tour bus, Ferrum, Virginia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Roddy Moore, director of the Blue Ridge Institute at Ferrum College, asked me to photograph Ralph Stanley while he and his band were playing at the Ferrum folklife festival. This photograph was taken on his bus after he had played an hour-long show outside in freezing weather under an open sided tent. He was not happy that he was expected to play under such conditions and was warming himself with a down comforter before autographing CDs. He said, however, that after so many years on the road, he had come to expect just about anything and that he was looking forward to a more comfortable venue at his next concert in Tallahasee, Florida the following day.

did.unittitle: Rud Shupik, Callands, Virginia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Rud Shupik plays Delta blues and rhythm and blues. He also operates an organic farm where he raises hogs and chickens which he sells at farmer's markets.

did.unittitle: Wyatt Oakes and his sister, Virginia Oakes Edwards at their homeplace, Callands, Virginia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Wyatt Oakes farmed tobacco on his family farm in the Callands community of Pittsylvania County, Virginia. He served in the Korean conflict as an infantryman, 1952-53. He would never consent to an oral history but was a great neighbor and grew beautiful tobacco. Mr. Oakes introduced me to Rogers Royal, another local tobacco farmer who still cured his tobacco with wood - the last farmer in Pittsylvania County to do so. (See portraits of Royal in the Virginia series)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: These 31 11x14 inch black-and-white gelatin silver images were taken by photographer Jesse Pyrant Andrews on November 19, 2010 during a train trip from New York City to Lynchburg, Virginia. Images were chiefly taken from the windows of the moving train and captured overpasses, traffic, graffiti, residential neighborhoods, train stations, and other urban landscapes. A few shots focus on train passengers and there is one of a railroad worker on the tracks, as well as the photographer's self-portrait.

Prints are untitled; descriptions in brackets have been supplied by library staff. All of the photographs were printed in 2011 and 2012. Original print numbers assigned by the photographer have been retained, and each print has been given an institutional identifier. Prints are arranged in order as originally received.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Comprises 61 11x14 inch black-and-white (gelatin silver) photographs scenes taken mainly in the Halifax, Virginia area; other locations include Danville, Virgilina, and Franklin and Pittsylvania Counties. Many of the portraits form part of the Carter-Wooding Project and the Veterans Project and are primarily of farmers and military veterans. Additional subjects include small business operators, townspeople, musicians, and rural farms and landscapes.

A note from the photographer on the the Carter-Wooding project: "The Carter-Wooding project is something I started in the late 1990s, documenting the 'old Carter farm' in Halifax County, where I now live. The property was originally a 5000-acre land grant from King George, divided into five parcels and given to the five (then) Carter brothers. As was common at that time, the Woodings and Carters intermarried over several generations, thus the name. The Woodings were prominent early settlers in both Halifax and Pittsylvania Counties. The Carters were prominent Virginia settlers since the beginning. The land grant extended from the Banister river, which borders the north side of Halifax (town), northward up what is now Rt. 501. It was probably little more than a footpath then. There are two fragments of the land grant remaining, one of them being a 200 acre parcel (the old Carter farm) and another smaller parcel located about a mile north of the other. One of them is owned by a friend of mine, who is in one of the photographs in the collection, an image of him standing in the doorway of the pack barn. His father is seated on the step in front of him. His father, Robert Wooding, died in 2004, and took a great deal of history with him. His son, Robbie (my friend) still lives on the farm and still grows a little dark-fired tobacco."
The prints are arranged in rough chronological order. Original titles, captions, and negative identifiers have been retained as assigned by Andrews.

scopecontent.p: Reid Carter was a mechanic who worked primarily on pulpwood trucks. He lived with his mother in a cabin without running water or electricity. When she died in 1982, at age 100, Reid lost his mind and was committed to a state mental institution in Staunton. He died a few months later.

did.unittitle: Edwin Wemple, Charlottesville, Virginia, 1976

dao.xlink:title: Edwin Wemple, Charlottesville, Va., 1976.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Ed Wemple grew up in Charlottesville and graduated from the University of Virginia. He wandered the country during the depression of the 1930s. He worked as a longshoreman in New York, in lumber camps in Oregon and eventually went to Mexico, where he became a heroin addict. He cured himself by walking from El Paso to the Oklahoma border. He returned to New York, where he lived until 1964, taking in the bohemian and jazz cultures and working at odd jobs. He returned to Charlottesville in 1964 and lived there until his death in 1987. I lived in the same house with him for a year. He had not had a bath in nine years and spent his time reading and sleeping. He went by taxi once a week to the Alderman Library to replenish his book supply. A wonderful man who had endless stories to tell about his life. I regret that I did not record any of our conversations.

did.unittitle: Matthew Lafayette Aaron ("Fate" Aaron)

dao.xlink:title: Matthew Lafayette Aaron ("Fate" Aaron)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Born Jan. 10, 1919 at Callands, Virginia. Grew up on a tobacco farm, enlisted in the Army in 1941, fought as an infantryman through North Africa, then as a Ranger through the Sicilian and Italian campaigns. Discharged November, 1945. Wounded three times in what he called "three years of continuous combat." As a Ranger he was usually at the forward most front of the fighting. He has suffered since his discharge with severe PTSD and alcoholism. In spite of that, as well as his physical wounds, he was a successful tobacco farmer until he retired in 1994. He lives on the same farm where he was born. Up to this time I have not been able to convince Mr. Aaron to agree to an oral history. When I made this photograph, he said, "I was a nice fellow when this picture was made (the portrait of himself he is holding), before I went overseas. Since then, I don't know, I just never have been the same." This is part of the Disabled Veterans series.
The oral history interview with Aaron was completed in 2012.

did.unittitle: Mrs. Maynard Amos, circa 2000-2006

dao.xlink:title: Mrs. Maynard Amos

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mrs. Maynard Amos operated Amos' General Store at Callands, Virginia. with her husband until he suffered a stroke in 1999. Since then she has run the store on her own. One of only a handful of such rural businesses still in operation, it remains a gathering place for local farmers and a source for gasoline, farm supplies, groceries, patent medicines, and just about anything else a person might need.

did.unittitle: Frank Joseph Wilcosky, Halifax, Virginia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Frank Joseph Wilcosky (Wil), was born December 12, 1914 to Polish immigrant parents near Latrobe, Pennsylvania. His father worked in the anthracite coal mines. Mr. Wilcosky truly lived the "rags to riches" American dream. He died in 2009, having amassed a fortune through hard work and his imaginative business sense.
This print is accompanied by an oral history interview on two CDs.

did.unittitle: Earl Link, Alton, Virginia, 2013 September

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Earl Link, a lifelong tobacco farmer, still lives on the farm where he was born in Halifax County, Virginia. He learned to play the fiddle from his uncles, who taught him the American old time fiddle style, which preceded bluegrass. In the 1940s, as bluegrass became more popular, he taught himself to play in that genre. Earl played with many bands for almost 60 years.

did.unittitle: Sam Winstead, dancing with his granddaughter at a Veterans For Peace fundraiser near Leasburg, North Carolina, 2015 June

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sam Winstead is a 93 year old Marine Corps veteran of WW 2. He fought at Peleliu and Okinawa, more than 100 days of continuous combat which the Marine Corps archives describe as the most horrific fighting in the history of the Corps. In 2007, after decades of trying to find peace within himself and forgiveness for the Japanese he fought in those battles, he founded Americans For Peace, along with its adjunct Veterans For Peace, and began an annual event called Sam's Ride for Peace. Since 2010, he and others have travelled by bicycle from Raleigh, N.C. to Washington, D.C., an annual eight day ride to promote peace in the world, stopping at schools and community centers along the way to advance their message.

did.unittitle: Abandoned tobacco curing barn, Pittsylvania County, Virginia, 2015 July

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This curing barn is unusual in that it is built with a cinderblock foundation and with framed walls, as opposed to the traditional log-bodied structures that typically had foundations of field stones, with mud daubing between the logs. This barn had been covered with cement stucco, much of which has fallen off, revealing cured but badly deteriorated tobacco still hanging from the tier poles inside. The sign in front of the barn reflects the sentiments of many of the citizens of Pittsylvania County, as well as surrounding counties, in response to the efforts of Walter Coles to convince the state legislature to allow him to mine a potential 119,000,000 pound deposit of uranium that lies under his land, on the Colonial-era estate known as Coles Hill, located about fifteen miles northwest of where this barn stands.
For additional history notes, please refer to the caption list in the box containing this print.

did.unittitle: Tractor accident, Rice, Virginia, 1998

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mary Lou Wood waits with her son, "Little Man" to learn the fate of her husband, Doug Wood, after he turned over a huge tractor while bush-hogging on an embankment a few minutes earlier. The owner of the dairy farm on which the Woods worked as tenants was on his way to the scene of the accident. Miraculously, Doug Wood was not seriously injured but the tractor was badly damaged. Farming is dangerous business. The Woods family left Rice for West Virginia soon after this event took place.

did.unittitle: Abandoned satellite dish, Shooting Creek Road, Franklin County, Virginia, 2015 May

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Franklin County, Virginia, has long enjoyed the dubious, albeit somewhat romantic reputation as the "moonshine capitol of the world." Franklin County is where the now fabled "moonshine conspiracy" took place in the 1930s, the subject of Dr. Charles Thompson's book Spirits of Just Men. During that time almost everyone in the county was involved in one way or another in the production of white liquor, everyone from the county sheriff all the way down to small children, who often acted as lookouts and laborers at the numerous stills that dotted the mountainsides, well hidden in the rhododendron and mountain laurel groves. Shooting Creek Road (State Route 860) was where many of the stills were located, and runs for several miles between Rocky Mount, the county seat of Franklin County, and Floyd County, located to the west.
For additional history notes, please refer to the caption list in the box containing this print.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Chef Steve Schopen opened the Molasses Grill restaurant in Halifax in 2005, and has had ten very successful years as owner and head chef of that business. Born in Kent, England, in 1957, Steve has cooked all over the world. Schooled in the classic French style, he went on to learn many different styles of cooking at the restaurants in which he worked as a cook, finally earning the title "Chef" after coming to the United States in 1983. This is part of the Halifax project. An oral history accompanies this print.

did.unittitle: Herman Martin, Danville, Virginia, 2016 January

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mr. Martin celebrated his 90th birthday February 3 of 2016. Born in the Calloway community of Franklin County, Virginia, he moved to Danville, Virginia, at age 15 to work in the Dan River Cotton Mill. He lost his right arm in a hunting accident when he was 16, but continued to work at Dan River until his retirement in 1990. Before losing his arm he had been an accomplished guitar player, playing what is now referred to as "American old time music." After the accident, he learned to play the same tunes on harmonica, and continues to play three or four times a week with friends. He knows many of the old fiddle tunes and has a wonderful musical style, sometimes playing two harmonicas at one time to accommodate key changes in a particular tune.

did.unittitle: Floyd Sutphin, South Boston, Virginia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: At age fourteen, Floyd Sutphin left the farm near South Boston, Virginia, where he was born, and migrated to Atlantic City, New Jersey, where he got work in the kitchen of a large hotel. At sixteen, he moved to Manhattan and settled in Harlem, where he again worked in a hotel kitchen. At eighteen, he and a partner opened the DeLuxe Barbeque Restaurant on 146th St. at 7th Ave. He operated that business for twenty years before moving back to South Boston to care for his elderly parents. Oral history accompanies this print.

did.unittitle: Robert Wooding cutting tobacco plants for spiking, 2014 September

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Robbie still grows "dark-fired" tobacco, a variety called Lizard Tail. Unlike flue-cured tobacco (Brightleaf), which is harvested leaf by leaf, dark-fired tobacco plants are cut low to the ground and the entire plant impaled on a standard tobacco stick, several plants to a stick. The sticks are then hung on the tier poles of the curing barn, just as with flue-cured tobacco. Once the barn is full, several small, smoldering fires are built on the interior dirt floor and the barn is shut up as tightly as possible. Robbie makes these fires of hickory and cedar wood. The heat and smoke from these fires dries and flavors the tobacco, a three or four day process. The result is dark-colored leaves and a strong smoky taste when the tobacco is smoked or chewed. Robbie sells some of his crop and sets aside a portion for his own use. Dark-fired tobacco has become less and less common since the industrialization of tobacco farming in the 1990s.

did.unittitle: Danny Newton loading sticks of Lizard Tail tobacco onto the truck for transport to the curing barn, Halifax County, Virginia, 2014 September

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Danny is Robert Wooding's brother-in-law, married to Robbie's younger sister, Susan, who is handing Danny the sticks. Danny raises Bright Leaf tobacco and cattle near Nelson, Virginia. I have never seen Danny in a bad humor.

did.unittitle: Interior of curing barn, old Carter farm, Halifax County, Virginia, 2014 September

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Here are the small fires Robert Wooding sets in the barn to cure his dark-fired tobacco. Part of the smoke necessarily escapes from the cracks and holes in the barn, sometimes giving the mistaken impression that the barn is afire. When the growing of dark-fired tobacco was more common, fire departments sometimes got false calls reporting a burning barn.

did.unittitle: Robert Wooding plowing his garden beside the old Carter farm home, 2012

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Carter house was built in three sections, the first (middle) section around 1790. The front section was added about 1840, and the kitchen, a log-bodied room, was added in 1886. Legend has it that the huge rock chimneys flanking the original section were built by a woman, although her name is long forgotten. Robbie's grandmother, Elizabeth Carter, was the last permanent resident of the house. Robbie still uses the kitchen. The rest of the house is used as a guest house and family gathering place.

did.unittitle: Kitchen, old Carter farmhouse, 2016 January
Hallway, old Carter farmhouse, 2016 January
Farm sale, Easley farm, Pittsylvania County, Virginia, 1976 October

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This was the first farm sale I photographed. This sale was of the Easley homeplace, where my ancestor Pyrant Easley, born in 1742, settled and built his home in 1772, after leaving Halifax County, Virginia, where he orginally settled around 1764. He was a son of John Easley, who settled in Cumberland County, Virginia, circa 1735. The Easleys were Huguenots who fled France in the late 1600s, after Louis XIV revoked, in 1685, the Treaty of Nantes, which had granted vast privileges to the Huguenots. More than 10,000 Huguenots left France for America at that time. Pyrant Easley the elder died in 1816, leaving the home and several hundred acres of land to his son, also named Pyrant, born 1805. The younger Pyrant's grandson, Robert Henry Easley, was my grandfather. Robert's brother, Jesse Pyrant Easley, for whom I am named, was living in the original homeplace on the farm when he died in 1975 at age 91, leaving no will. Consequently, the farm was sold at public auction. A cousin bought the property at the sale, and so it remains in the family still. No one now lives in the original house, but is is being well maintained by the fmaily. It is one of two early homes in Pittsylvania County that were built in an "H" configuration. The Pittsylvania Easleys have always farmed tobacco, and continue to do so even now.

did.unittitle: Farm sale, Pearson farm, Climax, Virginia, 2004

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Originally settled by John Richmond Pearson. He married Alsee Boswell, born 1883. Alsee was the older sister of my maternal grandmother, Vivian Boswell, born 1903. Vivian married Robert Easley in 1920 (see notes regarding the Easley farm sale). The Pearsons had eleven children, most of whom stayed on the farm and raised tobacco. One son, Thomas was killed when he was struck by lightning while plowing with a mule. John and Alsee's children are all deceased, although some descendants still live on the farm. Tobacco is no longer grown on that land. The homeplace, scene of this photograph, burned to the ground in April, 2016.

did.unittitle: Dr. Roger Browne, South Boston, Virginia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Dr. Browne served as an Army surgeon in the Central Highlands of Vietnam, 1968-1969. First assigned as Battalion Surgeon to the 146th of the 198th Light Infantry Brigade, he had charge of 36 medics and worked primarily from LZ Bayonet and LZ Professional, near Chu Lai. He was later promoted to Brigade Surgeon of the entire 198th. He was present when LZ Professional was overrun by North Vietnamese troops on two occasions.
Accompanied by an oral history. Part of the Vietnams Project.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access

Assigned to the 1/46th of the 198th Light Infantry Brigade, he, like Dr. Browne, was on LZ Professional when it was overrun by North Vietnamese troops.
Oral history accompanies this print. Part of the Vietnam Project.

did.unittitle: Robert Aiken, South Boston, Virginia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Ninety-six year old Robert Aiken was part of a unique division of men who were trained by the Army specifically for the planned invasion of Japan in 1945. Told in training that they could expect 75% casualties on landing, they were nevertheless willing to go through with their mission. Mr. Aiken is an exceptionally cheerful man who has spent his life helping other people.
Oral history accompanies this print. Part of the Veterans Project.

Norma Reed Smith, 2003

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Born in Sparta, N.C., in 1917, Norma moved with her family to Danville, Virginia, at age 5. She began working at the Dan River Fabric Mill in 1932, at age fifteen. After seven years she was assigned to work in the spinning room, where she worked for the next forty years. She married Oscar Smith in 1946 and raised two sons, Jerry and Dennis. Norma died 7 November, 2005.

did.unittitle: Jerry Donald Smith, 1987

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Eldest son of Norma and Oscar Smith. A writer, currently living in Danville, Virginia.

did.unittitle: James Matthew Aaron on his 65th birthday, Callands, Virginia, 2012 December 7

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Born in 1947, Jim was the eldest son of Matthew Lafayette Aaron (see entry for earlier image). Because of a difficult birth, Jim was delivered with forceps, resulting in his having a minor deformity of his eyes. He also walked with a slight limp. Because the other children made fun of him, his father took him out of school after the first grade. He became his father's shadow and learned farming - how to grow a crop of tobacco, how to raise cattle, how to repair cars and machinery. Jim had an unfailing memory for details and loved Nascar and working with horses. After Mr. Aaron's death, Jim's health began to decline, and he died of congestive heart failure in 2015.

did.unittitle: Claude Swanson Shelton, Gretna, Virginia, 1976

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Born in Pittsylvania County, Virginia, in 1892, "Swannie" Shelton was my grandmother's first boyfriend. He played the fiddle and banjo, and, along with my grandmother's four brothers, had a string band. They played at house parties, dances, corn huskings, barn raisings, and weddings...just about any occasion that called for music, playing what we now know as "old time." The band broke up when Giles Boswell, my grandmother's brother, who, according to Swannie, was "a first-rate fiddle player," was killed in France at the second battle of Verdun. In the 1970s, my grandmother and I often visited Swannie at his barber shop in Gretna, where we would play a few tunes and the two of them would talk about "the old days." Swannie died in 1982. The street in Gretna where he had lived for years was named "Music Street" in his honor.

did.unittitle: Floyd Martin Fox, Sr., Weal, Virginia, 1980

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Floyd Fox was born in 1905. He farmed for a while as a young man, then went to work on a railroad construction crew. When he injured himself in a fall from a bridge, he returned to the farm and opened a store "on the road" in 1932. He sold farm supplies, seed, fertilizer, food, had a bar with slot machines, and sold gasoline. He used to boast that he had the oldest ABC license in Virginia. He extended credit to his farmer neighbors, and when the CCC established a camp nearby, his business became a popular place for the men in the camp to come and relax in the evening... [see inventory in box for more details]

did.unittitle: Burlington Mills

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These seven black-and-white portraits by photographer Jesse Andrews and the oral histories that accompany them form part of the Burlington Mills Project, which documents the lives of former employees of a Halifax, Virginia textile mill, and how they and their community have been affected by the mill's closure in 2002. The gelatin silver prints measure 11x14 inches, and are arranged in chronological order and then by original identifiers as assigned by the photographer.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Titles, captions, and original negative identifiers assigned by the photographer have been retained. Several prints in this series are unnumbered. Prints are arranged in rough chronological order according to the negative date.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series houses 54 11x14 inch black-and-white (gelatin silver) photographs. Most document people, culture, and landscapes of central Piedmont North Carolina and Virginia. One portrait is of a Vietnam Veteran, Joe Wilcosky, and includes an oral history. The rest of the photographs were taken in New York State, California, and Massachusetts. Images feature street scenes in Boston, buildings, and natural subjects such as plants and ice on a pond.

Other "Life At Large" images are also found in the Virginia series, marked in the legacy identifiers as "LAL." Photographs of some of the same people in this series can also be found in the Portraits series.

Statue of Robert E. Lee covered with a tarp, Lee Park, Charlottesville, Virginia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Whatever Lee believed, he has now become a symbol...signifying to some people an ancestral nightmare and to others an ancestral hero. Likewise the catchword "heritage" carries vastly different meanings depending on what one's ancestors were doing or having done to them 157 years ago. After he died, however, his image as a popular Southern hero overshadowed his own desire in life to put the past behind him. The tarp covering Lee's statue was removed in March of 2018 by order of Judge Richard Moore. The issue is still being debated by the Charolttesville city council.

Statue of Confederate soldier, erected by the United Daughters of the Confederacy in the early 20th century, Halifax County Courthouse, Halifax, Virginia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Hundreds of statues similar to this one were put up across the South by the UDC in the years just before WWI and in the 1920s. The Halifax County Courthouse is slated for extensive renovation which will drastically alter the historic faade of this building. Built in 1838 by Dabney Cosby, the building is on the National Reister of Historic Places. This statue will probably be removed as a part of the renovation.

did.unittitle: At Mountain View Plantation, Tightsqueeze, Virginia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Built in 1790, Mountain View was the home of a lifelong friend, Steven Law, who died unexpectedly September 1, 2018. Mountain View was owned by generations of Steven's family. I spent many days and nights there in the 66 years I knew Steven. To be at Mountain View was to transcend time and place. He owned this 1960 Corvette, and drove it for many years, often exceeding 140 mph. He parked it in the yard at Mountain View in 2002, believing that if he continued his thrill-seeking it would eventually kill him. It is currently returning to the earth, as is Steven.

did.unittitle: At Mountain View Plantation

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A fourth-story window, looking south toward the family cemetery. Steven attempted to preserve Mountain View as it had always been. Plumbing and electricity were added by his parents in the 1930s. Otherwise it remains basically unchanged.

scopecontent.p: Originally this building housed the kitchen, separated from the main house in case of fire. Steven's father James Law, an architect, used it for his office.

Trumpster dumpsters, Halifax County, Virginia
Billboard, Halifax, Virginia
Frank Joseph Wilcosky, Jr., Halifax County, Virginia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Joe grew up in Fort Lauderdale, Florida. He joined the U.S. Navy at age 17, served on a destroyer (USS Cory) and an aircraft carrier before volunteering for riverboat duty in Vietnam in 1967. He was assigned to the Mobile Riverine force at Dong Tam, an American base south of Saigon in the Mekong Delta, and served there 1968-1969. The Riverines served as support troops for the 9th Inf. Division, also based at Dong Tam, ferrying troops upriver to firefights and lending support, often going ashore to participate in the fighting when the 9th Inf. Troops got into a tight spot. Joe was a jack of all trades, serving in whatever capacity was needed, everything from fighting fires during the daily mortar and rocket attacks at Dong Tam to accompanying troops upriver. Discharged in 1969, he returned to Fort Lauderdale and worked as a postal carrier until his retirement after 29 years. Joe now lives part time in Fort Lauderdale and part time here in Halifax Co. He is a close friend.
An oral history and release form accompany this print. Part of the Vietnam Veterans Project.

did.unittitle: Auction sale at Mountain View

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The house and land, 164 acres,did not sell at this auction since no bid was offered that met the owner's reserve.The personal property and household furniture were sold that day. Stephen Burwell Law, who inherited Mountain View from his parents,leftthe propertyto his sister, Laura, who had not lived there since 1968.Laura had no interest in living there and so put it up for sale.The house andland were sold by a realtor in September, 2020.The new owners have vowed to maintain Mountain View as closely as possible to its original condition, according to the stipulation Steve put forth in the directive he left with his will. Steve had maintained it for years,making every effort to retain its historic integrity. He did not want Mountain View to fall into the hands of someone who would "modernize" the house by turning it into a bed and breakfast or a wedding venue.Laura did as he wished, and I know Steve would be glad that his wishes are being honored.

did.unittitle: Jesse Pruitt at Fox's road house (Red Fox Inn), Pittsylvania County, Virginia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Fox's was originally owned by Floyd Fox, Jr., and his brother Bill Fox. They were sons of Floyd Fox, Sr., who also operated a road house (see print in Virginia series). The Red Fox inn was a local watering hole and meeting place for many years. Jesse Pruitt was an extraordinary pool player and usually "ran the table" on anyone willing to challenge him - meaning that his opponent almost never got a shot - his challenger in this image can be seen sitting to the left, waiting to lose and pay up. Jesse would clear the table and walk away with the wager.

did.unittitle: Abandoned church, Halifax County, Virginia
The old general store at the Ingram community, Halifax County, Virginia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A crossroads community, Ingram was once a thriving place, when tobacco was still the economic mainstay of the Old Belt region. This store was the center of the community's commercial activity, where just about anything was available - clothing, shoes, hardware, fresh meat and vegetables - whatever anyone might need. Credit was available, with no interest charged. If a farmer was cash poor, credit was extended until his crop sold in the Fall. The store was also a meeting place for the local residents to sit and play checkers and talk, or just visit and discuss the important topics of the day - weather, politics, who had the best-looking tobacco, who might need help with their crop. The loss of these community hubs has meant that in many places like Ingram, the people living there have grown less close and become busy with the mundane activities of more modern times - driving half an hour to buy what they could previously get at the general store, from people they don't know who work in businesses owned by people who are not local and only see customers as a source of profit.

did.unittitle: Farm supply building, a part of the Ingram general store, Halifax County, Virginia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Where farm supplies were kept for sale at the general store. Anything a farmer might need, including blasting powder, was available.

did.unittitle: Confederate statue during renovation of the Halifax County courthouse

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Here is the memorialized rebel, still overseeing the workers. During the summer of 2020 a petition was drawn up to remove the statue either altogether or move it to a more appropriate place, such as the county museum. Hundreds of local residents signed the petition, but the county board of supervisors passed the buck (after pleas from the "heritage not hate" contingent), deciding to place the issue on the ballot in the next county election. Meanwhile, the 20 million-dollar plus renovation of the 1838 structure continues.
